Question Text: Another term for POTS, or Plain Old Telephone Service, is _______________.
Choices:
a. Public Available Telephone Network
b. Public Switched Telephone Exchange
c. Phone Switched Transport Network
d. Public Switched Telephone Network
e. Public Available Telephone Exchange
LLM Explanation: POTS, or Plain Old Telephone Service, is another term for the Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN). The PSTN is the aggregate of the world's public circuit-switched telephone networks, which provides infrastructure and services for public telecommunication.

Question Text: A baud rate is a measurement of the number of ______________________.
Choices:
a. bits that can be sent across a telephone line every minute
b. bytes that can be sent across a telephone line every second
c. bits that can be sent across a telephone line every second
d. bytes that can be sent across a telephone line every minute
LLM Explanation: A baud rate measures the number of bits that can be sent across a telephone line every second. It represents the signaling rate or symbol rate of a communication channel.
URLs: ['Forouzan, B. A. (2013). Data Communications and Networking (5th ed.). McGraw-Hill.', 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baud']

Question Text: What system did Duke grads build that is still in use today?
Choices:
a. POTS
b. PSTN
c. USENET
d. DSL
LLM Explanation: USENET, a worldwide distributed discussion system, was developed by graduate students Tom Truscott and Jim Ellis at Duke University in 1979. It allowed users to read and post messages (called articles or posts) to one or more categories, known as newsgroups. USENET was one of the first and most significant examples of a large scale computer network for communication between users. While its usage has declined with the rise of web forums, blogs, and social media, USENET is still in use today by some individuals and organizations.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usenet', 'https://www.britannica.com/technology/USENET', 'Kurose, James F., and Keith W. Ross. Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach. Pearson, 2017.']

Question Text: Which device is used to transfer data across a dial-up connection?
Choices:
a. ATM
b. Modem
c. Ethernet cables
d. USENET
LLM Explanation: A modem (modulator-demodulator) is used to transfer data across a dial-up connection. It converts digital signals from a computer into analog signals that can be transmitted over telephone lines and then converts the analog signals back into digital signals at the receiving end.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modem']

Question Text: Modems take data that computers can understand and turn them into _____ that can be transmitted over POTS.
Choices:
a. Audible wavelengths
b. Baud rates
c. Modulating electrical charges
d. PSTN
LLM Explanation: Modems convert digital data from computers into analog signals (audible wavelengths) that can be transmitted over Plain Old Telephone Service (POTS) lines. The modem modulates the digital data into audible tones for transmission and demodulates the tones back into digital data on the receiving end.
URLs: ['CompTIA A+ Certification All-in-One Exam Guide, Tenth Edition (Exams 220-1001 & 220-1002) by Mike Meyers', 'Networking All-in-One For Dummies, 7th Edition by Doug Lowe']

Choices:
a. Transmission 1
b. Transportation 1
c. Transmission System 1
d. Transportation System 1
LLM Explanation: T1, in the context of computer networking, stands for 'Transmission 1'. It refers to a digital transmission system that carries data at the rate of 1.544 Mbps (megabits per second). T1 lines are commonly used for connecting networks across remote distances and were widely used in the early days of the Internet.

Question Text: How fast is a T1 line?
Choices:
a. 128 Mb/sec
b. 1.544 Mb/sec
c. 1 Mb/sec
d. 44.763 Mb/sec
LLM Explanation: A T1 line is a dedicated digital carrier line that supports data rates of 1.544 megabits per second (Mb/sec). It is a widely used leased line option for businesses requiring reliable, high-speed data connectivity. The other options listed are incorrect: 128 Mb/sec is the speed of OC-3 lines, 1 Mb/sec is a common broadband internet speed, and 44.763 Mb/sec is the speed of a T3 line.

Question Text: Select all statements that are true of cable internet connections.
Choices:
a. They're wireless connections
b. They're broadband connections
c. They're dial-up connections
d. They're shared bandwidth connections
LLM Explanation: Cable internet connections are broadband connections that provide high-speed internet access using the same coaxial cables that deliver cable television signals. They are not wireless connections, as they require a physical cable connection to the home. Cable connections are also not dial-up connections, which use telephone lines and are much slower. One characteristic of cable internet is that the bandwidth is shared among users in the same neighborhood, which can lead to slower speeds during peak usage times.

Question Text: What are the subprotocols for PPP (Point to Point Protocol)? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. FCS
b. LCP
c. Compression
d. NCP
LLM Explanation: The two main subprotocols of PPP are:b. LCP (Link Control Protocol): Establishes, configures, and tests the data-link connection. It is responsible for negotiating authentication, encryption, and compression options.d. NCP (Network Control Protocol): A series of protocols, each of which is specific to a particular network layer protocol, such as IPCP for IP, IPXCP for IPX, etc. NCPs are responsible for configuring the network layer protocol parameters.The other options are not subprotocols of PPP:a. FCS (Frame Check Sequence): A field in the PPP frame used for error detection, but not a subprotocol.c. Compression: A feature that can be negotiated by LCP, but not a subprotocol itself.
URLs: ['Forouzan, B. A. (2013). Data Communications and Networking (5th ed.). McGraw-Hill Education.', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/wan/point-to-point-protocol-ppp/10241-ppp-overview.html']

Question Text: What do you call the demarcation point for fiber technologies?
Choices:
a. ONT
b. FTTN
c. FTTX
d. DSLAM
LLM Explanation: The demarcation point for fiber technologies is called an Optical Network Terminal (ONT). The ONT is the device installed at the customer premises that terminates the fiber optic line from the service provider and converts the optical signal into electrical signals for connection to the customer's network devices.

Choices:
a. Wireless Local Area Network
b. Wireless Area Network
c. Wired Area Network
d. Wide Area Network
LLM Explanation: WAN stands for Wide Area Network. A WAN is a computer network that extends over a large geographic area, connecting different LANs (Local Area Networks) and MANs (Metropolitan Area Networks). WANs enable communication between computers and devices in different cities, countries, or even continents, using various technologies such as leased lines, satellites, and the Internet.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/switches/what-is-a-wan-wide-area-network.html']

Question Text: In a WAN, what is the area between a demarcation point and the ISP's core network known as?
Choices:
a. a local loop
b. a Local Area Network
c. A local link
d. An access point
LLM Explanation: In a Wide Area Network (WAN), the area between a demarcation point (the point where the responsibility for the network switches from the customer to the service provider) and the Internet Service Provider's (ISP) core network is known as the local loop. It is the physical link or circuit that connects the customer's premises to the ISP's nearest point of presence or central office.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom']

Question Text: A point-to-point VPN is also known as a ______________.
Choices:
a. port forwarding VPN
b. one-to-many VPN
c. data link VPN
d. site-to-site VPN
LLM Explanation: A point-to-point VPN is also known as a site-to-site VPN. It connects two specific sites, such as two branch offices of a company, over a secure encrypted tunnel. The VPN gateways at each site handle the encryption, decryption, and routing of traffic between the sites, making it appear as if they are directly connected despite being geographically separated.
URLs: ['NIST SP 800-77 Rev. 1, Guide to IPsec VPNs, https://csrc.nist.gov/publications/detail/sp/800-77/rev-1/final', 'Cisco Networking Academy, Connecting Networks v7.0, Module 3: Point-to-Point Connections']

Question Text: Who handles sending data from one site to another?
Choices:
a. T-carrier line
b. CTO
c. ISP
d. VPN
LLM Explanation: An Internet Service Provider (ISP) is responsible for sending data from one site to another over the Internet. ISPs provide the infrastructure and services that enable data transmission between different networks and sites across the globe.

Question Text: How many address fields does an 802.11 header contain?
LLM Explanation: The 802.11 header contains 3 address fields. These are used to specify the source address, destination address, and the BSSID (Basic Service Set Identifier) which identifies the access point. The fourth address field is optional and used only in ad hoc mode.
URLs: ['IEEE 802.11-2016 - IEEE Standard for Information technology—Telecommunications and information exchange between systems Local and metropolitan area networks—Specific requirements - Part 11: Wireless LAN Medium Access Control (MAC) and Physical Layer (PHY) Specifications', 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/802.11_Frame_Types']

Choices:
a. a collision domain
b. a point-to-point wireless connection
c. an example of an ad-hoc network
d. Individual, smaller sections of the overall frequency band used by a wireless network
LLM Explanation: Wireless channels are individual, smaller sections of the overall frequency band used by a wireless network. They allow multiple devices to communicate simultaneously without interfering with each other by using different channels within the same frequency band.
URLs: ['CWNA Certified Wireless Network Administrator Study Guide by David D. Coleman and David A. Westcott', 'Wireless Networks For Dummies by Barry D. Lewis']

Question Text: Which of the following frequencies do wireless networks typically operate on? Select all that apply.
LLM Explanation: Wireless networks typically operate on the 2.4GHz and 5GHz frequency bands. The 2.4GHz band is more widely used and compatible with more devices, while the 5GHz band offers faster speeds and less interference but has a shorter range. The other frequencies listed (1.544GHz and 88MHz) are not commonly used for Wi-Fi networks.

Question Text: WPA3 was built with the intention of replacing which protocol?
Choices:
a. WPA2
b. WLAN
c. WEP
d. IEEE 802.11
LLM Explanation: WPA3 (Wi-Fi Protected Access 3) was developed to replace WPA2 (Wi-Fi Protected Access 2). WPA3 aims to enhance wireless security by introducing more robust authentication and encryption mechanisms compared to its predecessor, WPA2. Some key improvements in WPA3 include protection against offline dictionary attacks, forward secrecy, and enhanced security for open networks.
URLs: ['Wi-Fi Alliance. (2018). Wi-Fi Alliance® introduces Wi-Fi CERTIFIED WPA3™ security. https://www.wi-fi.org/news-events/newsroom/wi-fi-alliance-introduces-wi-fi-certified-wpa3-security', 'Cisco. (2018). Wi-Fi Protected Access 3 (WPA3). https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/wireless/what-is-wpa3.html']

Question Text: An 802.11 frame contains a number of fields. Which field describes the version of 802.11 that is being used?
Choices:
a. Sequence control
b. Frame control
c. Address
d. Duration
LLM Explanation: The frame control field in an 802.11 frame contains information that defines the type of 802.11 frame and provides information required for the following fields to understand how to process the frame. This includes the protocol version, which specifies the version of the 802.11 standard being used.
URLs: ['IEEE 802.11-2016 - IEEE Standard for Information technology—Telecommunications and information exchange between systems Local and metropolitan area networks—Specific requirements - Part 11: Wireless LAN Medium Access Control (MAC) and Physical Layer (PHY) Specifications', 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/802.11_Frame_Types']
